Augmentation of a pyramid solar still performance using evacuated tubes and nanofluid: Experimental approach Swellam W. Sharshira,b,c, A.W. Kandealc, M. Ismaild, Gamal B. Abdelazize, A.E. Kabeelf,⁎, Nuo Yanga,⁎
a State Key Laboratory of Coal Combustion, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, China b School of Optical and Electronic Information, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, China cMechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Kafrelsheikh University, 33516 Kafrelsheikh, Egypt dMechanical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Suez University, Egypt eMechanical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Egypt fMechanical Power Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Tanta, Egypt
H I G H L I G H T S
• Investigated the effect of using evacuated tubes integrated with pyramid still.• Conducted the effect of using evacuated tubes with copper oxide and carbon black integrated with pyramid still.• Copper oxide and carbon black leads to improve the freshwater by about 27.85% and 33.59%.• Maximum thermal efficiency was about 64.5% for the modified pyramid still with carbon black.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Solar energy Desalination Pyramid solar still Evacuated tube Nanofluids Copper oxide Carbon black
A B S T R A C T
This paper presents an experimental approach of a new hybrid system of modified pyramid solar still combined with evacuated tubes and nanofluids for high thermal performance. The current work compares between the performance and costs of three different units; one reference conventional solar still (CSS) and a couple of pyramid solar stills namely: conventional pyramid solar still (CPSS) and modified pyramid solar still (MPSS). The MPSS was integrated with evacuated tubes and, furtherly, nanofluids which are copper oxide (CuO) and carbon black (CB) nanomaterials with 1.5% wt. According to resulted data, the enhancement percentage in total freshwater was 4.77 and 26.6% in the case of MPSS over CPSS and CSS, respectively. Furthermore, the total freshwater was improved by about 27.85 and 54.48% in case of MPSS with copper oxide over CPSS and CSS. Finally, the enhancement percentage in total freshwater was 33.59 and 57.098% in case of MPSS with carbon black over CPSS and CSS, respectively. Moreover, the daily efficiency (ηd) of MPSS reached 50% whereas it reached 61% and 64.5% in the case of MPSS with copper oxide and carbon black, respectively. On the other hand, ηd reached 48 and 30% for CPSS and CSS, respectively. Finally, the performed cost analysis shows that the proposed MPSS with nanofluids has economically reasonable with the offered optimal thermal performance.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Currently, the demand for freshwater is increasing along with the emergence of the population; however, unfortunately, less than 0.5% of freshwater proportion is reachable, and hence these resources are being over-depleted [1,2]. Thus, the appeal for making the abundant saline water suitable for domestic, irrigation and especially for drinking purposes witnesses an upward upsurge. One of the efficacious natural
solutions is solar desalination which depends on two abundantly available resources, almost everywhere on the earth, (saline water and the sun) [3,4]. Solar still (SS) is one of the best desalination techniques which features an uncomplicated construction, inexpensive, low operation efforts, low maintenance and eco-friendly [5]. Unfortunately, conventional solar still (CSS) has low productivity due to large loss of heat to surrounding and need a large amount of heat to heat the basin water [6]. So, its productivity enhancement has been done through

several works, which have investigated advancement of some designs, and operational conditions [7,8], thermal storage materials [9,10] tubular solar still [11], SS integrated with humidification and dehumidification [12–14] and so on. Moreover, to overcome the limitations of CSS, the pyramid solar still (PSS) has been carried out. For PSS, in contrary to CSS, has no need for
a solar tracking system [15], minimum shading effect of the side wall on the water surface [16] and larger condensation area [17]. Hamdan et al. [18] made theoretical and experimental comparisons on the performance of different multiple basin SSs with pyramid glass cover. respectively. Taamneh and Taamneh [19] examined the influence of forced convection on the daily productivity of a PSS integrated with a low power-consuming fan. They found that the productivity was improved by 25% as compared to free CSS. Furthermore, SS may be categorized by the source of the thermal energy used to evaporate the water into passive depending directly on the sun or active using a supplement [20] such as solar collectors [21], concentrators [22], and water heaters [23]. Rajaseenivasan et al. [24] investigated the effect of integrating flat plate collector to SS. The productivity was boosted by 60% over CSS. Whereas, Fathy et al. [25] studied the effect of integrating parabolic trough collector (PTC) to double slope SS. The experiments illustrated that, SS with fixed and tracked PTC enhanced the productivity by 89% and 142% over CSS, respectively. Flat plate collectors revealed considerable progress in SS performance; however, the flat plate collectors receive the solar radiation only from the top surface in addition to the need for circulation pump. On the contrary, the evacuated tubes collectors gave more efficient since the solar radiation is perpendicular to the surface of the tubes almost the day as well as not need moving parts [26]. Recently, after the revolution of nanotechnology, further efforts have been done studying the effect of using nanofluids on the performance of SSs [27,28]. Various water nanofluids namely: Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3), Zinc Oxide (ZnO), Iron Oxide (Fe2O3) and Tin Oxide (SnO2) were tested in a CSS in which the productivity proportion witnessed an increase by 29.95% using Al2O3 nanofluid [29]. Sharshir
et al. [30] evaluated the impact of using copper oxide (CuO) and graphite flakes with glass cooling. The yield was promoted to about 53.95% and 44.91% over CSS utilizing the graphite flakes and CuO, respectively. Kabeel et al. [31] experimentally investigated the addition of Cu2O and Al2O3 solid nanoparticles. An increase in the production rate of 93.87% and 88.97% was observed Cu2O and Al2O3, respectively. Moreover, nanofluids have a great potential to enhance the solar thermal conversion efficiency [32] due to their several features of thermophysical properties compared to base fluid such as enhance heat transfer [33,34], large thermal conductivity [35,36], large absorptivity [9,28], and large surface area and low specific heat [37,38]. Various nanomaterials have been used to improve the water evaporation, for example, plasmonic metals [39], plasmonic nanofluid [40] carbonbased materials [41,42], TiO2 nanoparticles mixed with black paint [43], heat localization [44] and thin film evaporation [45]. The novelty of this work is to effectively enhance the performance of PSS by using attached evacuated tubes to improve saline water heating and accelerate its evaporation, as well as the freshwater productivity. Furthermore, the effect of utilizing two different types of nanomaterials with high thermophysical properties and large surface area, which are copper oxide (CuO) and carbon black (CB) as nanofluids, is experimentally investigated in depth. The main outcomes of these contributions will help to significantly increase the solar absorbance and thermal conductivity and decrease the specific heat capacity. As a result, increase the thermal performance of PSS and the corresponding enhancement in productivity.

sections.heading: 2. Test-rig description and instrumentation
sections.text:
The investigated system was well prepared and manufactured from economical and locally available materials and was augmented by proper instruments to measure its performance parameters. The following sections discuss in detail the specifications of both the system components and instrumentation. The system consisted of three stills, one of them was CSS while the others were the pyramidal ones which are the conventional pyramid solar still (CPSS) and modified pyramid solar still (MPSS) of type A, with evacuated tubes, and type B, with evacuated tubes and nanofluids, as illustrated in Fig. 1-(a). All stills matched in both fabrication material and insulation technique as they were made from 1.5 cm-thick blackpainted steel and well insulated with 5 cm-thick glass wool material
secured by 2 cm-thick outer wooden frames. Furthermore, for CSS, it had a rectangular basin of 100 cm length and 50 cm width with 15 and 44 cm height for front and back sides, respectively. It was covered by 4mm-thick glass cover tilted at 30° with the horizontal facing south. On the other hand, both of CPSS and MPSSs were made in the shape of a square basin of 75 cm length and 75 cm width having 20 cm height and covered with 4mm-thick pyramidal glass cover of 30° tilt angle. The southern side of MPSSs had apertures formed to allow glass vacuum tubes to penetrate the duct and provided with triple-edged silicone seals to prevent water leakage. Six tubes of 5.8 cm diameter and 180 cm length coated with AL-N/AL heat absorption coating were used. They were positioned facing south and inclined to the horizontal at 45°. Saline water samples were gathered from the Mediterranean Sea in plastic tanks shown in Fig. 1-(b) and transported to the experiment location in Kafrelsheikh city, Egypt. System specifications and dimensions are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Measuring instruments
sections.text:
Various performance affecting parameters were measured which are wind velocity, solar radiation, and temperature at several locations. The measurement techniques depended basically on electronic units and sensors. A solar radiation sensor was used to measure solar irradiance. For temperature, LM 35 temperature sensor with an accuracy of 0.5 °C was used to measure the temperature of water surface, glass inner and outer temperature, ambient temperature and basin water temperature.
All measured data were recorded in on a memory card using Arduino Mega (with 15 analog inputs and 53 digital I/O pins) for further analysis. The power needed for electronic components operation was obtained from a PV-system consisting of PV panel, charger, and battery. Additionally, freshwater was collected in scaled bottles connected to the stills. Sensors positions are illustrated in the schematic shown in Fig. 2. Used devices were perfectly calibrated according to lab equipment. The overall error percentages of temperature sensors were minimized through AD590 calibration sensor. Also, the solar radiation sensor was calibrated by positioning it at 30° and changing reading according to a calibrated Pyranometer.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: As previously mentioned, the current work aims to evaluate the performance of PSS by, firstly, integrating evacuated tubes to the PSS basin and furtherly involving nanofluids. The units experimented at the same time in outdoor conditions under the weather of Kafrelsheikh city, Egypt (31°05′54″N and 30°57′00″E). The following sections discuss in detail the obtained results and the enhancement portions.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of nanoparticles and nanofluids
sections.text:
To enhance the solar absorption and heat transfer of the pure water, carbon black (CB) and copper oxide (CuO) nanoparticles are dispersed
in the water with 1.5% wt concentration. Fig. 3-(a) and (b) show the morphology of the surface and the nanomaterials size measured by using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The figure illustrates the good homogenous dispersion of nanoparticles in water. Also, it was found that the CB and CuO nanoparticles have a spherical shape, where the average size of nanoparticles is around 40 nm in diameter, and also nanoparticles are aggregated to small clusters. The absorption spectra of CB, CuO nanoparticles, water, and nanofluids that used in this work were measured by using UV–Vis at 400 to 1100 nm wavelength as given in Fig. 3 (c) and (d). The absorption of the pure CB nanoparticles is almost constant with a value of 98% in the whole range of wavelength. On the other side, the absorption spectra of pure CuO nanoparticle is changed with different wavelengths. The maximum value was founded to be 96% at a small range of wavelength from 400 to 500 nm. After that, it quickly decreases until it reached 73% at 900 nm wavelength, then the variation of the absorption spectra keeps stable at large wavelength from 900 to 1100 as illustrated in Fig. 3-(c). Furthermore, Fig. 3-(d) shows the absorption of CB nanofluids, CuO nanofluids, and water. It can be seen that the CB nanofluids have full absorption approximately equal to 99.999 at the entire wavelength. Additionally, CuO nanofluids have perfect absorption near to 99.99 at a low wavelength from 400 to 800 nm after that the absorption of CuO nanofluids decreased from 99.99 at 800 nm to reach the lowest value of 94 at 1100 nm as illustrated in Fig. 3-(d). Moreover, the pure water has a low value of absorption at all wavelength, especially at low wavelength from 400 to 800 nm as in Fig. 3 (d). From the previous discussion, the experimental results indicate a better solar absorption capability by using nanofluids due to the nanofluids have a threedimensional absorbing structure, compared to the pure nanoparticles. It should mention that, because of the lower water depth in the basin of the solar still, the nanoparticles will be suspended in the base fluid to make nanofluids.
3.2. Thermo-physical properties of the base fluid, nanoparticles, and nanofluids
Recently, the use of solar thermal energy and nanotechnology are the extremely common in a variety of applications. The nanofluids have great potential to enhance the energy efficiency and heat transfer. This attributed to the several merits compared to base fluid (i.e. water) such as large thermal conductivity, large absorptivity and low specific heat. As a result, improving the heat transfer properties, and therefore the water evaporation [42,46] which increase the freshwater output from the solar distiller [30]. Properties of both the nanoparticles (see Tables 2) and the base fluid (see Table 3) are used to determine the different thermophysical properties of nanofluids tabulated in Table 4.
3.2.1. Prediction of thermal conductivity, specific heat and density of nanofluids It is recognized that the suspension of solid nanoparticles in the base liquids can enhance coefficient of heat transfer [33,53] and thermal conductivity [54,55]. We try to predict the thermal conductivity of the base fluid and nanofluids at different temperature levels in the range of the experimental study from 30 °C to 90 °C as illustrated in Fig. 4-(a) based on the mathematical correlations given in Tables 2, 3 and 4. It is concluded from the figure that the nanofluids have a higher thermal conductivity than the base fluid at different temperature ranges, and
this totally consistent with [56–58], and so improve the rate of evaporations as well as the freshwater production. Moreover, the thermal conductivity of the nanofluids and base fluid increase with the temperature. Specific heat capacity is indispensable to investigate the system thermal performances. Fig. 4-(b) illustrates the prediction of specific heat for the base fluid, 1.5 CuO nanofluid, and 1.5 CB nanofluid. Also, the specific heat of different fluid slightly increases with the temperature increase. To add with, the specific heat of base fluid is remarkably higher that of nanofluids at different temperatures due to the small heat capacity of nanoparticles compared to with base fluid it is fully consistent with [37,38]. Moreover, the specific heat of CuO nanofluid is remarkably less than that the CB nanofluid due to that the heat capacity of CuO is small than the CB nanoparticles as mentioned in Table 2. It is concluded that the specific heat decrement of nanofluids and the increase the thermal conductivity of nanofluids helps the nanofluids to heat up quickly compared to the base fluid, and consequently increase the rate of evaporation and freshwater production. Fig. 4-(c) illustrates the prediction of density for the base fluid and CB nanofluid, and CuO nanofluid. Obviously, the figure shows that the CB and CuO nanofluids have higher densities (CuO 6500 kg/m3, CB 1750 kg/m3) than that the base fluid (995 kg/m3) at different temperatures ranging from 30 °C to 90 °C. However, the density of nanofluid and base fluid decreases extremely modest with temperature, due to the influence on the base fluid, which agrees with [59].

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of attaching evacuated tube to PSS basin
sections.text:
Series of experiments were conducted to ensure the effect of integrating evacuated tubes to PSS. However, results were taken on 25th May 2018 are presented in Fig. 4 as an example for illustration. For Fig. 5-(a), the hourly ambient air temperatures and maximum values of solar radiation incident (IR) at the southern side, where the evacuated tubes are positioned, are presented. It is evident that the values of IR follow the ordinary contour of variation as they vary from 300W/m2 at 8:00 reaching a peak value of 950W/m2 at noon and finally decrease again in the afternoon period to 120W/m2 at 18:00 falling to zero at night. Additionally, the ambient air temperatures (Ta) take the same trend of variation from 28 °C at 8:00 to 29 °C at 18:00 falling to 26 °C at night with a peak-level-off value of 33.5 °C between 11:00 and 12:00. By comparing the values of water temperature (Tw), Fig. 5-(b), the preceding of CPSS over CSS is approximately constant during the day with an average value of 2 °C. But for MPSS, the antemeridian hours witness values of Tw close to CPSS with average enhancement of 1.6 °C, whilst the afternoon hours record high improvement reaching about 24 °C over CPSS. Also, it can be noticed that Tw of both of CSS and PSS reaches a maximum value at 13:00 in contrary to 14:00 in case of MPSS, because of the quantity of water in the case of MPSS is much more than PSS and CSS, and hence, the time consumed for water heating is longer. As a result, the evacuated tubes worked as thermal storage leading to the high difference in Tw in day late-hours. Moreover, the values of glass outer temperature (Tgo) during the day is illustrated in Fig. 5-(c). As shown, CSS and CPSS have semi-coincide values with little average difference of 0.1 °C throughout the day as they begin with 33 and 36 °C at 8:00 reaching 48 and 48.5 °C at 13:00 and decrease to 27.5 and 27 °C at 22:00, respectively. In the other word, for MPSS, the values begin with 32 °C at 8:00 till the maximum value of 54 °C at 14:00 then down to 33 °C at 22:00. The obvious large difference
between MPSS and others at afternoon hours backs to the higher values of Tw and hence the vapor temperatures which lead to heating the glass cover through rejected heat amount. The same trend of variations and enhancement during the day is also found in case of both hourly yield (m), Fig. 4 (d), and accumulative
productivity (md), Fig. 5-(e). The rapprochement in values in the early hours is due to the needed time to heat the amount of water which is higher in the case of MPSS compared to other units. Moreover, the large improvement in productivity during late hours backs to heat capacity of water in the evacuated tubes, and that is why they are regarded as thermal storage medium. Form, the values begin with no gain at 8:00 reaching 0.6, 0.65 kg/m2 at 13:00 for CSS and CPSS and 0.475 kg/m2 at 14:00 in case of MPSS. Later, the values decrease to 0.002, 0.00 and 0.1 kg at 22:00 for CSS, CPSS, and MPSS, respectively. On the other hand, the values of md vary from zero at 8:00 to 3.12, 3.77 and 3.95 kg/ m2 at 22:00 for CSS, CPSS, and MPSS, respectively. The enhancement percentage in total freshwater md is 4.77% and 26.6% in the case of MPSS over CPSS and CSS, respectively. In general, the case of MPSS with evacuated tube require more water to fill the tubes. Thus it will need more time to be heated, hence the productivity is not high in this system.

As is observed, the radiation intensity began with a value of 300W/m2 at 8:00 reaching its maximum value of 990W/m2 at 12:00 before decreasing continuously to its minimum value of 180W/m2 at 18:00. Simultaneously, the ambient temperature was ranged from 27 to 35 °C. The relative ratio of CuO to water was selected at 1.5% wt. Fig. 6-(b) reveals the comparison of Tw between the provided units. In the morning, the water temperature continuously changed with approximately close values in the CSS, CPSS, and MPSS till noon. Then, MPSS with CuO recorded a higher value of Tw since the water temperature was enhanced by the evacuated tube collector. This due to the
large absorption capability of CuO nanofluid than the base fluid as mentioned above in Fig. 3-b, the decrease of specific heat of nanofluid, and increase the thermal conductivity of CuO nanofluid, which helps the CuO nanofluid to heat up quickly compared to base fluid. The maximum value noticed to be 86 °C at 14:00 for MPSS with CuO, 72 °C at 13:00 for CPSS and 69 °C at 13:00 for CSS. Similarly, the Tgo did not witness a high change between the different stills before 12:00. Results showed that the glass outer temperatures of MPSS with CuO exceeded CPSS by about 4 –10 °C as illustrated in Fig. 6-(c). Consequently, the hourly yield of MPSS with CuO was always higher than that of CPSS and CSS. The maximum hourly productivity was 0.53 kg/m2 at 14:00
for MPSS with CuO. Fig. 4-(d) indicates that the productivity rate of MPSS with CuO had a considerable upsurge compared to conventional stills from 14:00 to 22:00. On the other hand, the values of md vary from zero at 8:00 to 3.21, 3.71 and 4.82 kg/m2 at 22:00 for CSS, CPSS, and MPSS, respectively which is higher than that of CPSS and CSS by 27.85 and 54.48% respectively as illustrated in Fig. 6-(e). The increase in water temperature is accompanied by the increase in evaporation rate, and thus increase the productivity in the MPSS with CuO compared with the CSS and CPSS. This is mainly attributed to the characteristics of the CuO nanofluid as mentioned in the Sections 3.1 and 3.2. Furthermore, the CPSS give a higher performance compared to the CSS due to the minimum shading effect of the side wall on the water
surface and larger condensation area.

sections.heading: 3.5. Influence of carbon black nanofluid on the performance of MPSS
sections.text:
Carbon black (CB) was used as a second type of nanofluids utilized to improve the performance of MPSS. The relative ratio of CB to water was selected at 1.5% wt. Series of experimental measurements were conducted ensuring the stability of the enhancement gained by additing of CB. A sample of the resulted experimental data at 29th June 2018 is illustrated in Fig. 7. During the day, according to Fig. 7-(a), the maximum IR intensity measured on the southern side varies from 440W/m2 at 8:00 am to 190W/m2 at 18:00 with peak value of 1030W/m2 at
noon and falls to zero when sunset. Simultaneously, the corresponding values of ambient temperature vary from 31 to 28 °C at 8:00 and 22:00, respectively, with hump of 36 °C at noon. A large amount of water in case of MPSS with CB lags the heating which can be noticed from the closely of Tw of CSS, PSS, and MPSS with CB at day early hours with an average difference of 2.8 °C as shown in Fig. 7-(b). Also, for the same reason, the peak value of Tw was recorded of 86.5 °C at 14:00 in case of MPSS with CB compared to CSS and CPSS which had a peak value of Tw at 13:00 of 70 and 72 °C, respectively. The heat capacity of MPSS with Cb water kept high values of temperature for day late-hours even though sunset hours as the values reached 42,
33 and 30 °C in case of MPSS with CB, CPSS, and CSS, respectively. The values of Tgo follow the same trend of Tw as all units had close values in first five hours of measurements with small average difference of 1.2 °C in the sake of MPSS with CB over CPSS as shown in Fig. 7-(c). Also, the peak value was 56 °C at 14:00 in case of MPSS with CB but that of CPSS and CSS were 50 and 49 °C, respectively, at 13:00. Moreover, Tgo reached 35, 28 and 28 °C at 22:00 for MPSS with CB, CPSS, and CSS, respectively. The variation ofm and md during the day are presented in Fig. 7-(d) and Fig. 7-(e), respectively. Form, the values start with zero at 8:00 reaching peak values of 0.61, 0.65 kg/m2 at 13:00 for CSS and CPSS,
respectively, and 0.56 kg/m2 at 14:00 in case of MPSS with CB. By the end of measurement at 22:00, values decrease to 0.001, 0.003 and 0.118 kg/m2 for CSS, CPSS and MPSS with CB, respectively. On the other hand, the values of md vary from no gain at 8:00 to 3.24, 3.81 and 5.09 kg/m2 at 22:00 for CSS, CPSS and MPSS with CB, respectively. The enhancement percentage in md is 33.59 and 57.098% in case of MPSS with CB over CPSS and CSS, respectively. We can observe the considerable improvement of the absorptivity, the decrease of the specific heat and the increase of the thermal conductivity of CB nanofluid compared to CuO nanofluid and also base fluid (see Fig. 3 and Fig. 4). As a result, this will help the CB nanofluid to heat up quickly compared to CuO nanofluid and base fluid and consequently increase the rate of evaporation and then freshwater production.

sections.heading: 5. Cost evaluation
sections.text:
The constant price (CP) of the CSS is nearly about 85 $ USD as stated in
Table 5. To get the average value of the water productivity cost, it is significant to know the variable price (VP) as well as the overall constant price (OCP), where OCP=CP+VP. Consider VP equalize 0.3 CP yearly according to [60], thereafter OCP=85+0.30×85×10=340 $. The average water production per day from the CSS was about 2.50 L/m2.day. To calculate the annual cost of one liter of freshwater, we assumed the still works about 340 days per year and the predicted life of the still time is about ten years. The overall freshwater through the lifetime of the still=2.5×10×340=8500 L. The price of one liter of the freshwater from CSS equals to 0.04 $ (340/8500). In addition, the total fixed and variable costs when using the CPSS=360 $ wherever the average freshwater can be predestined 3 L/m2 day. Furthermore, the total freshwater through the life of CPSS is=10200 L. The price of one litter from the CPSS is 0.035 $ (360/ 10200). Whereas, when using MPSS; the total fixed and variable costs=500 $ and the average freshwater can be predestined 3.3 L/m2.day. The total freshwater through the life of MPSS is=11220 L. The price of 1 litter from the MPSS equals 0.044 $ (500/11220). The total fixed and variable costs when using the MPSS with CB; the total constant and variable costs= 540 $ and the average freshwater can be predestined 4.3 L/m2.day. The total freshwater through the life of MPSS with CB was= 14620 L. The price of one litter from the MPSS with CB is 0.036$ (540/14620). Whereas, when using MPSS with CuO, the value of OCP=580 $, wherever the average freshwater can be predestined 4 L/m2 day. Also, the total freshwater through the life of MPSS with CuO was=13600 L. The price of one litter from the MPSS with CuO 0.042 $ (580/ 13600).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: In this work, three SSs (CSS, CPSS, and MPSS) have been experimentally fabricated and investigated to figure out the effect of using evacuated tubes and nanoparticles on the performance of the PSS. Two types of nanofluids (CuO and CB) with high thermophysical properties and large surface area were proposed and integrated into the evacuated tube-based PSS system to improve saline water heating and accelerate its evaporation, as well as the freshwater productivity. Also, a comprehensive comparison in terms of system productivity, efficiency and costs of the proposed MPSS systems (with and without nanomaterials), CPSS, and CSS at the same operating conditions is presented. The main results illustrated that the enhancement percentage in the total freshwater was 4.77 and 26.6 in case of MPSS compared to CPSS and CSS, respectively. Also, in case of MPSS with CuO, the total freshwater improved by about 27.85% and 54.48% compared to CPSS and CSS, respectively. In addition to that, using CB nanoparticles with MPSS gave the best enhancement which increased the total freshwater by about 33.59% and 57.098 compared to CPSS and CSS, respectively. Furthermore, the daily thermal efficiency of MPSS alone and MPSS integrated with CuO and CB nanoparticles was about 50%, 61%, and 64.5%, respectively. On the contrary, it was about 47–48% for CPSS and 30% for CSS. Finally, the cost of one-liter freshwater was found to be about 0.042 $, 0.035 $ for CSS and CPSS, respectively and 0.045 $, 0.042 $ and 0.036 $, respectively for MPSS, MPSS with CuO and MPSS with CB.

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents an experimental approach of a new hybrid system of modified pyramid solar still combined with evacuated tubes and nanofluids for high thermal performance. The current work compares between the performance and costs of three different units; one reference conventional solar still (CSS) and a couple of pyramid solar stills namely: conventional pyramid solar still (CPSS) and modified pyramid solar still (MPSS). The MPSS was integrated with evacuated tubes and, furtherly, nanofluids which are copper oxide (CuO) and carbon black (CB) nanomaterials with 1.5% wt. According to resulted data, the enhancement percentage in total freshwater was 4.77 and 26.6% in the case of MPSS over CPSS and CSS, respectively. Furthermore, the total freshwater was improved by about 27.85 and 54.48% in case of MPSS with copper oxide over CPSS and CSS. Finally, the enhancement percentage in total freshwater was 33.59 and 57.098% in case of MPSS with carbon black over CPSS and CSS, respectively. Moreover, the daily efficiency (ηd) of MPSS reached 50% whereas it reached 61% and 64.5% in the case of MPSS with copper oxide and carbon black, respectively. On the other hand, ηd reached 48 and 30% for CPSS and CSS, respectively. Finally, the performed cost analysis shows that the proposed MPSS with nanofluids has economically reasonable with the offered optimal thermal performance.
